lines.name: 1 Train
lines.description: The 1 train is a Broadway–Seventh Avenue local service and one of the original subway lines, having opened on the first day of New York City subway operations in 1904. It runs the full length of the Upper West Side from Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to the southern tip of Manhattan.

lines.name: 2 Train
lines.description: The 2 train is a Seventh Avenue express service running from Wakefield in the northern Bronx through Manhattan to Flatbush in Brooklyn. It shares its trunk line with the 1 and 3 trains but operates as an express through Midtown and the Upper West Side.

lines.name: 3 Train
lines.description: The 3 train is a Seventh Avenue express service connecting Harlem to New Lots Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. It runs express alongside the 2 train through Manhattan before branching onto the Livonia Avenue Line in Brooklyn.

lines.name: 4 Train
lines.description: The 4 train is a Lexington Avenue express service running from Woodlawn in the Bronx to Crown Heights in Brooklyn. It is one of the most heavily used subway services, carrying enormous ridership through the Lexington Avenue corridor in Midtown Manhattan.

lines.name: 5 Train
lines.description: The 5 train is a Lexington Avenue express service connecting the Dyre Avenue line in the northeast Bronx to Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. It shares its trunk line with the 4 and 6 trains on the busiest rail corridor in North America.

lines.name: 6 Train
lines.description: The 6 train is a Lexington Avenue local service running from Pelham Bay Park in the northeast Bronx to Brooklyn Bridge–City Hall in Lower Manhattan. It was part of the original 1904 subway and is consistently one of the system's busiest lines.

lines.name: 7 Train
lines.description: The 7 train is the Flushing line, running from Main Street in Flushing, Queens to 34th Street–Hudson Yards in Manhattan. Known as the International Express for the diverse immigrant communities along its elevated route through Queens, it was extended to Hudson Yards in 2015.

lines.name: N Train
lines.description: The N train runs from Astoria in Queens via the Broadway express tracks in Manhattan to Coney Island along the Sea Beach Line in Brooklyn. It crosses the Manhattan Bridge and serves as one of the primary connections between Queens and Brooklyn.

lines.name: Q Train
lines.description: The Q train runs from 96th Street on the Second Avenue Subway through Midtown Manhattan and across the Manhattan Bridge to Coney Island via the Brighton Line. Its northern extension onto the Second Avenue Subway opened in 2017, bringing service to the Upper East Side.

lines.name: R Train
lines.description: The R train is a Broadway local service running from Forest Hills in Queens through the Montague Street Tunnel to Bay Ridge in southwestern Brooklyn. It is the only subway service to Bay Ridge and one of the few lines using the Montague Street Tunnel.

lines.name: W Train
lines.description: The W train is a Broadway local service running from Astoria in Queens to Whitehall Street in Lower Manhattan. Discontinued in 2010 and restored in 2016, it provides local service along Broadway in Manhattan complementing the express N train.

lines.name: B Train
lines.description: The B train is a Sixth Avenue express service running from 145th Street in Harlem across the Manhattan Bridge to Brighton Beach in Brooklyn. It operates weekdays only and shares its Brighton Line tracks with the Q train.

lines.name: D Train
lines.description: The D train is a Sixth Avenue express service running from Norwood in the Bronx across the Manhattan Bridge to Coney Island via the West End Line in Brooklyn. It is one of the longest services and one of the few that passes through three boroughs.

lines.name: J Train
lines.description: The J train is a Nassau Street local service running from Jamaica Center in Queens over the Williamsburg Bridge to Lower Manhattan. It runs largely on elevated structure through Brooklyn neighborhoods including Bushwick, Cypress Hills, and Woodhaven.

lines.name: Z Train
lines.description: The Z train is a Nassau Street express service operating in the peak rush-hour direction only, skip-stopping along the Jamaica Line in Brooklyn and Queens. It shares its entire route with the J train and was created to relieve overcrowding on that line.

lines.name: L Train
lines.description: The L train is the 14th Street–Canarsie local, the only service on its line and one of the few crosstown routes in the system. It connects Chelsea and the West Village in Manhattan to Williamsburg, Bushwick, and Canarsie in Brooklyn via the 14th Street Tunnel.

lines.name: M Train
lines.description: The M train is a Sixth Avenue local service running from Forest Hills in Queens through Manhattan to Middle Village–Metropolitan Avenue via the Myrtle Avenue Line in Brooklyn. It follows an unusual looping route connecting central Queens to Bushwick and Ridgewood.

lines.name: A Train
lines.description: The A train is the longest service in the New York City subway system, running over 31 miles from Inwood at the northern tip of Manhattan to Far Rockaway in Queens. Made famous by Billy Strayhorn's jazz standard, it also branches to Ozone Park–Lefferts Blvd and serves as the Eighth Avenue express.

lines.name: C Train
lines.description: The C train is an Eighth Avenue local service running from Washington Heights to Euclid Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. It provides local stops along the Eighth Avenue and Fulton Street corridors, complementing the express A train.

lines.name: E Train
lines.description: The E train runs from Jamaica Center in Queens to the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan via the Queens Boulevard and Eighth Avenue lines. It is one of the primary airport connections, linking to the AirTrain at Sutphin Blvd–Archer Av–JFK Airport station.

lines.name: F Train
lines.description: The F train is a Sixth Avenue local service and one of the longest routes in the system, running from Jamaica in eastern Queens through Manhattan to Coney Island via the Culver Line in Brooklyn. It passes through diverse neighborhoods including the Lower East Side, Park Slope, and Kensington.

lines.name: G Train
lines.description: The G train is the only subway service that does not enter Manhattan, running crosstown between Long Island City in Queens and Church Avenue in Brooklyn. Known as the Brooklyn–Queens Crosstown, it provides a vital link between the two boroughs through Greenpoint, Williamsburg, and Park Slope.

lines.name: 42 St Shuttle
lines.description: The 42nd Street Shuttle is a short back-and-forth service connecting Times Square to Grand Central Terminal along 42nd Street. Originally part of the first subway line in 1904, it became a standalone shuttle in 1918 and is one of the busiest short-distance rail links in the world.

lines.name: Franklin Av Shuttle
lines.description: The Franklin Avenue Shuttle is one of the oldest rail lines in Brooklyn, predating the subway system itself with origins in 1878. It provides a short north-south connection between the Franklin Avenue and Prospect Park stations, linking the A/C and B/Q/S lines.

lines.name: Rockaway Park Shuttle
lines.description: The Rockaway Park Shuttle connects Broad Channel to the Rockaway Park peninsula, branching off from the main A train route across Jamaica Bay. It runs on a former Long Island Rail Road right-of-way acquired by the city in 1956.
